So I'll try to share a little bit about what the world looks
like from the perspective of a core developer, right?
Who worked on Ethereum previously.
This is relevant in the context of my work on Space Mesh
and I think just any core developer.
We have this notion of a TCB.
TCB means trusted compute base.
And what it means is that there is some amount of code,
which is 100% critical to the functioning of the network,
and any bugs or vulnerabilities or exploits
in this inside the trusted compute base
are kind of apocalyptic, right?
They're kind of like stop the world scenarios,
like many of the exploits we're talking about here.
And this is not new to crypto.
It's not new to Web3, right?
This concept has existed forever.
It's present in operating systems and things like this.
But as a core developer, touching upon what you said
a moment ago about kind of the diff,
looking at the changes that optimism has had to make
to existing code like Go Ethereum or anyone building,
let's say modifying or tweaking or adding on
to existing code, this is what keeps us up at night
as core developers.
We want those changes to be as small as possible,
those diffs, ideally, to be on the order of tens of lines
rather than hundreds or thousands of lines.
Because every one of those represents a very real possibility
of the introduction of a bug.
Another principle of computer science
is that there's no such thing as bug-free code.
It doesn't matter how good of an engineer you are,
it doesn't matter how good your software engineering practices
are, there's some number.
And you can reduce it.
You can reduce the incidence of bugs
by following best practices, which, again,
have existed for decades, things like code reviews,
pair programming, there's various techniques.
But it can only go so low.
I think Microsoft or someone did research on this a decade ago
and found that the most senior, most experienced programmers
are still introducing one bug for every thousand lines
of code, period.
One bug for every thousand lines of code.
Go Ethereum is probably on the order of 100,000 lines of code.
And let's say some of those bugs have been found,
but there's still bugs there for sure.
So anyway, just as a comment, as a core developer,
like this is literally what keeps us up at night,
we want to minimize the number of changes.
And that's very, very difficult when
we want to add features and bells and whistles,
add new opcodes to our VM.
What's another good example?
A lot of blockchains are using WebAssembly as a VM now.

This thing called Ewasm, which was a candidate
to replace EVM after the merge.
WebAssembly is a whole complex ecosystem.
And if we start putting WebAssembly-based smart contracts
on chain, then all of a sudden, the compilers
and interpreters for WebAssembly are now
inside the trusted compute base.
So you've added 100,000 lines of code
or something to your trusted compute base.
So one-- I'm jumping ahead here,
but one potential mitigation strategy
is to really minimize the number of changes,
the number of things you add, minimize the size
of your trusted compute base.

So this is a very well-understood concept

One, there's bugs in your TCB.

I would go a bit further than just saying two-factor.

The whole concept of getting hacked

Go to a URL that's a phishing URL, click on something,

That's the vulnerability of the system,

If it's possible to have a button that you push right next

and you push the wrong button and it destroys the world,
the problem is not the person pushing the buttons.
The problem is the person who designed the buttons

So you really need to have a single sign-on

If an employee here, it's very common

You want to be able to immediately revoke

So I think essentially if you have administrative credentials

doing any sort of action on treasury, anything like that,
and you don't have the ability to revoke
those credentials remotely on loss
in a single, like five minutes after the event is reported,
you are making a big mistake.
And if it's possible for a user to go to the wrong URL

or use their keys incorrectly,
you're also making a big mistake.
So single sign-on and a hardware enforced key credentialing
are the way to go.
But luckily the broader security industry

And we now have things like pass keys on iOS

We also have great open source SSO tools

But one of the biggest problems with security

The defender needs to be protected against everything.
And you get a lot of cases where--
I mean, everyone knows as a team,
like you have a certain number of hours in a week
for your people.
And you want to spend your resources on building the product.
Because if your company fails, if your project fails,
no one uses it because you don't have any features.

So if you have one hour to spend,

So there's a lot of cases where the floor of security

There's a vulnerability and things like that.
So I think making tools better, making things secure by default,

So one thing I want to touch on with adapting web

Yeah, I agree with that stuff.
I mean, we're kind of jumping ahead a little bit

So having multi signatures, having cool off periods or delays,

I don't know if people are familiar with this,

The reason that the white hat hackers

Yeah, in general, you have the frequency

We also have more of a culture of bug bounties and reporting.

So that's an argument for possibly increasing the amount.
Like, there's a whole calculus.
If you offer people too much for reporting bugs,

And yeah, people probably--

I would obviously say you should pay as large amount

But you have the same risk with insiders.
One of the whole categories that crypto companies do not

You can have a team.
If a team is a few people that have started a project together

that's one level of trust.
But if you've got a team that's hundreds of people,
you're hiring people using LinkedIn and whatever else.
Somebody joins.

They could be nation state affiliated.

They may discover something in the course of their work

There's all sorts of stuff like that.

You have a trade off.

Flash loans are interesting.
And actually, you probably only hear about them in negative context.
But they're actually a net positive for the ecosystem.
They're actually very useful.
So flash loan basically allows you to borrow a nearly unlimited sum of money
without having any money yourself.
But you have to do it within a single transaction.
So at the end of the transaction, say there's multiple lines that make up
a transaction, you have to repay that loan at the end of it.
So people use it a lot for arbitrage bots or keeper bots, liquidation bots.
These keep financial markets in order because coder who has the skills to run these things,
but not the capital, too, can use flash loans to, say, borrow a million dollars

So they allow you to pay a very small amount of interest.
I mean, it probably amounts to thousands or tens of thousands of APY on an annualized basis.
But because it's for the span of a single block time, a tiny amount of interest,
and just just jack up to a very high level, a very high amount of leverage.
The amount of funds you're moving around and using in that single transaction.
And that can flow down.
Some of the most sophisticated flash loans,
they touch dozens and dozens and dozens of different contracts.

So I think there's like two classes of counterstraction.
So just to define the term very generally, counter abstraction is essentially when you
make no distinction between smart contracts and individual wallets.
On Ethereum right now, individual wallets are fundamentally different than smart contracts
because individual wallets are public, private key pairs.
Smart contracts are derived very differently.
And I don't necessarily have time to go into that right now.
But in counter abstraction, they're basically the same.
Smart contracts, individual wallets are smart contracts.
And we have the ability to do that right now with things like multisigs, which obviously
are somewhat valuable.
And in the future, we may eventually end up doing away with the distinction entirely.
So people with roll-ups were trying to do that, but eventually ended up deciding not
to because making these kind of protocol level changes just made it very difficult for Ethereum
developers to kind of propose and build on them.
So nice to make out of counter abstraction is design spaces is very wide.
